content: If it really improves efficiency/cohesion, as the article says, then why not. ++http://www.defensenews.com/story.php?i=4008143&c=EUR&s=TOP quote: Property Sales to Fund 'French Pentagon' Building By pierre tran Published: 26 Mar 11:45 EDT (15:45 GMT) PARIS - About 800 million to 1 billion euros ($1.1 billion to $1.36 billion) will flow into French Ministry of Defense coffers toward the end of the year or early 2010 as announced property sales proceed - part of a plan to bring 10,000 civilian and military personnel together in a new purpose-built headquarters at the gritty Balard site, Defense Minister Hervé Morin said March 26. The money will come from the disposal of a dozen or so buildings around the capital and is needed to meet a budgetary bow wave from equipment deliveries falling due in the next couple of years. "Financial estimates are going on," Morin told a press conference when asked about the amount from property sales. "Between 800 million to 1 billion euros" is expected, he said. At the Sept. 26 presentation of the 2009 defense budget, the figure of 1 billion euros was given for property divestments, topped up with 600 million euros from the sale of radio frequencies for the start of digital television broadcast. The properties will be sold to a holding company, Sovafim, owned by state bank Caisse des Depots et Consignations, which will pay the MoD. The buildings will be sold into the commercial market over time. The ministry is in negotiations on the sale terms, such as a share in any gains on resale. The sales are part of a large-scale plan to build new headquarters, dubbed the "French Pentagon," at the Balard site on the southwestern edge of the capital, bringing together under one roof the MoD; chiefs of staff of the Air Force, Army and Navy; the Délégation Générale pour l'Armement (DGA) procurement office; and the Sécretariat Génerale pour l'Administration, the administrative arm. The move is intended as a significant reform, promising a "strengthened cohesion" by bringing together key personnel from around the ministry, including the operational planning and command center, which Morin made clear deserved better than its present shabby accommodations. (...) The new headquarters are due to be ready in 2014, spread over 13,000 hectares and 300,000 square meters of office space. The present building for the MoD, the Hotel de Brienne, which served as the interim headquarters of Gen. Charles de Gaulle on the liberation of Paris in 1944, will be kept in state ownership, as will the elegant naval building, which faces the Place de la Concorde. A delta-winged Mirage fighter tilted at a dynamic angle signals use of the present Balard site as home to Airbase 117, near the Périphérique ring road that circles the capital.
